The most significant risk factor is persistent infection with human papillomavirus (HPV), particularly high-risk strains such as HPV16. Early detection is critical. Common early symptoms of anal cancer include rectal bleeding, anal itching, pain, or the presence of a lump or mass near the anus. High-risk individuals—such as those with HIV, immunosuppression, or a history of HPV-related cancers or precancerous lesions—should undergo regular screening with digital rectal examination (DRE) and anoscopy as recommended by their healthcare provider.
